data.title: Construction of Immersed Tube Tunnels
data.meta_description: Immersed Tube Tunnels are a type of underwater tunnel used for transportation, typically for roads or railways. They are constructed by immersing precast concrete segments, also known as tunnel…
data.text:
Immersed Tube Tunnels are a type of underwater tunnel used for transportation, typically for roads or railways. They are constructed by immersing precast concrete segments, also known as tunnel elements, into a prepared trench on the seabed.

Here are some key aspects and details you can include in your blog post:

Detailed Construction Process:

Casting basin and tunnel elements

Constructing the casting basin for fabrication the tunnel elements

Constructing the first batch of tunnel elements

Construct the temporary water ballast system

Seal the element with a temporary bulkhead

Fill the casting basin (inundation)

Remove the basin gate

Floating, trimming and winching the elements out of the basin and transport them to the immersion site one by one or a temporary parking parking place

Prepare the elements for the immersion process

Immersion

Dredge the trench for the tunnel

Construct a gravel bed at bottom of the trench

Immerse the tunnel element to its final place in the dredged trench

Connect the element by pumping and emptying water from of space between the bulkheads (Water pressure on the free end of the new element compresses and seal the rubber joint between the two elements)

Backfill material is placed on the sides and over the tunnel , to fill the trench and permanently bury the tunnel

Ballast the element on-site

Establishing the closure joint and the tunnel is open

Tunnel installations

Parallel to immersion process, refurbishing of the the tunnel can be carried out in the elements already in place.

Design Considerations:

Seismic Activity: Immersed Tube Tunnels must be designed to withstand seismic events and movements of the seabed.

Water Pressure: The tunnel structure should be designed to withstand the hydrostatic pressure exerted by the water column above it.

Navigation Clearance: Sufficient clearance is provided within the tunnel to accommodate the passage of ships and other marine vessels.

Ventilation and Lighting: Proper ventilation and lighting systems are essential for maintaining a safe environment within the tunnel.

Stages of Construction

Video Demonstration

Advantages of Immersed Tube Tunnels:

Cost-Effectiveness: Immersed Tube Tunnels often prove to be more cost-effective than other tunneling methods, especially for underwater crossings.

Minimal Disruption: The construction of immersed tube tunnels causes minimal disruption to marine traffic and the surrounding environment during the construction phase.

Durability: Immersed Tube Tunnels are designed to be highly durable and have a long service life.

Notable Examples:

Michigan Central Railroad (first tunnel in 1910): The Michigan Central Railroad tunnel, opened in 1910, is a historic immersed tube tunnel located beneath the Detroit River, connecting Detroit, Michigan, in the United States, with Windsor, Ontario, in Canada. It was the first tunnel to be constructed using the immersed tube method in North America. The tunnel facilitated the transportation of freight and passengers between the two countries and played a crucial role in promoting trade and economic development in the region.

Airport Express (MTR): The Airport Express is a railway line operated by the Mass Transit Railway (MTR) in Hong Kong. The line features an immersed tube tunnel section that connects the urban areas of Hong Kong with the Hong Kong International Airport on Chek Lap Kok Island. The immersed tube tunnel provides a reliable and efficient transportation link, allowing travelers to conveniently access the airport from various parts of the city.

Marmaray (world’s deepest immersed tunnel): The Marmaray project is an ambitious transportation infrastructure initiative located in Istanbul, Turkey. It includes the construction of the Marmaray Tunnel, which is the world’s deepest immersed tunnel. The tunnel passes beneath the Bosporus Strait, connecting the European and Asian sides of Istanbul. It serves as a critical railway link, enhancing connectivity and reducing travel times for commuters and passengers traveling between the two continents.

Cross-Harbour Tunnel: The Cross-Harbour Tunnel is a vital transportation artery in Hong Kong, providing an underwater connection beneath Victoria Harbour. Opened in 1972, it was the first tunnel in the city to utilize the immersed tube method. The tunnel accommodates both road and vehicular traffic, significantly easing congestion and facilitating smooth transportation between the Hong Kong Island and Kowloon Peninsula.

Eastern Harbour Crossing: The Eastern Harbour Crossing is another important immersed tube tunnel in Hong Kong. It forms part of the Route 4 highway system and connects Quarry Bay on Hong Kong Island with Lei Yue Mun on the eastern side of the Kowloon Peninsula. The tunnel plays a crucial role in facilitating cross-harbor vehicular traffic, improving accessibility, and reducing congestion in the region.

Sha Tin to Central Link: The Sha Tin to Central Link is a major railway project in Hong Kong aimed at enhancing transportation connectivity. It involves the construction of various tunnels, including immersed tube tunnels, to extend the existing rail network from the New Territories to the central business district. The immersed tube tunnels provide efficient and reliable transport links, contributing to the overall development and accessibility of the city.

Tsuen Wan Line: The Tsuen Wan Line is one of the Mass Transit Railway (MTR) lines in Hong Kong. It includes a section of immersed tube tunnel that passes beneath Victoria Harbour, connecting the urban areas of Tsuen Wan in the New Territories with Central on Hong Kong Island. The Tsuen Wan Line, with its immersed tube tunnel segment, has been instrumental in providing a convenient and efficient transportation option for residents and commuters.

Western Harbour Crossing: The Western Harbour Crossing is a major road tunnel located in Hong Kong. It provides a vital transportation link between the island of Hong Kong and the western part of the Kowloon Peninsula. The tunnel, with its immersed tube sections, significantly improves accessibility and reduces travel time for motorists, particularly those commuting between the densely populated areas of Hong Kong Island and Kowloon.

Busan–Geoje Fixed Link: The Busan–Geoje Fixed Link is an extensive transportation infrastructure project in South Korea. It consists of a series of bridges and tunnels, including an immersed tube tunnel, connecting the city of Busan with Geoje Island. The immersed tube tunnel section plays a crucial role in facilitating transportation and promoting regional development by providing a seamless connection between the mainland and the island.

Tokyo Bay Aqua-Line: The Tokyo Bay Aqua-Line is a notable expressway in Japan that combines bridges, causeways, and an immersed tube tunnel to cross Tokyo Bay. The immersed tube tunnel section enables motorists to travel between Kawasaki City and Kisarazu City, providing a faster and more convenient transportation option compared to alternative routes. The Aqua-Line serves as a vital link, enhancing regional connectivity and reducing travel time for commuters.

George Massey Tunnel: The George Massey Tunnel is an immersed tube tunnel located in British Columbia, Canada. It spans the Fraser River, connecting the communities of Richmond and Delta. The tunnel, a key part of Highway 99, plays a critical role in facilitating transportation along the route, improving connectivity, and easing traffic congestion in the region.

Louis-Hippolyte Lafontaine Bridge–Tunnel: The Louis-Hippolyte Lafontaine Bridge–Tunnel, located in Quebec, Canada, is an impressive combination of a cable-stayed bridge and an immersed tube tunnel. It carries Autoroute 25 over the Saint Lawrence River, connecting the island of Montreal with the South Shore. The immersed tube tunnel section of the project ensures smooth vehicular flow, offering a vital transportation link for commuters and travelers.

63rd Street Tunnel: The 63rd Street Tunnel is an immersed tube tunnel in New York City, United States. It forms part of the New York City Subway’s IND 63rd Street Line, connecting the boroughs of Manhattan and Queens. The tunnel provides an essential subway connection, improving transportation options and accessibility for residents and visitors in the area.

Baltimore Harbor Tunnel: The Baltimore Harbor Tunnel is a critical transportation route in Maryland, United States. It forms part of Interstate 895 and allows motorists to travel beneath the Patapsco River, connecting the city of Baltimore with the suburbs. The immersed tube tunnel section of the project serves as a vital conduit for regional transportation, facilitating the movement of people and goods.

Chesapeake Bay Bridge–Tunnel: The Chesapeake Bay Bridge–Tunnel, located in Virginia, United States, is an impressive engineering feat combining bridges and tunnels to cross the Chesapeake Bay. It consists of multiple immersed tube tunnel sections connected by bridges, providing a link between the Delmarva Peninsula and the mainland. The bridge-tunnel system is an iconic landmark and a crucial transportation artery, promoting economic development and facilitating travel in the region.

Downtown Tunnel: The Downtown Tunnel is a significant road tunnel in Virginia, United States. It connects the city of Portsmouth with the city of Norfolk, crossing under the Elizabeth River. The tunnel, featuring immersed tube sections, improves transportation connectivity, eases traffic congestion, and enhances accessibility between the two cities.

East Side Access: East Side Access is a major infrastructure project in New York City that aims to provide direct train service from the Long Island Rail Road (LIRR) to Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan. The project includes the construction of tunnels, including the 63rd Street Tunnel, which involves immersed tube sections. The tunnels and associated infrastructure will significantly enhance transportation options, reduce travel times, and improve connectivity for commuters traveling to and from Long Island.

Fort McHenry Tunnel: The Fort McHenry Tunnel is a major highway tunnel located in Baltimore, Maryland, United States. It carries Interstate 95 under the Patapsco River, connecting the neighborhoods of Locust Point and Canton. The tunnel, which incorporates immersed tube sections, is an essential transportation link that improves connectivity, reduces congestion, and enhances travel efficiency along the busy I-95 corridor.

Hampton Roads Bridge–Tunnel: The Hampton Roads Bridge–Tunnel (HRBT) is a significant infrastructure project in Virginia, United States. It spans the Hampton Roads harbor, connecting the cities of Hampton and Norfolk. The project includes a combination of bridges and immersed tube tunnels to facilitate transportation. The HRBT plays a crucial role in regional connectivity, allowing commuters and travelers to cross the harbor efficiently and promoting economic development in the area.

Midtown Tunnel (Virginia): The Midtown Tunnel is a prominent underwater tunnel in Virginia, United States. It runs beneath the Elizabeth River, connecting the city of Portsmouth with the city of Norfolk. The tunnel, featuring immersed tube sections, provides an essential link for vehicular traffic, improving accessibility, and reducing congestion in the Hampton Roads region.

Monitor–Merrimac Memorial Bridge–Tunnel: The Monitor–Merrimac Memorial Bridge–Tunnel, located in Virginia, United States, is a combination of bridges and tunnels that span the Hampton Roads harbor. The project connects the cities of Newport News and Suffolk and includes immersed tube tunnels as part of its structure. The bridge-tunnel system plays a crucial role in facilitating transportation and commerce in the region, enhancing connectivity between the Peninsula and the Southside of Hampton Roads.

Posey and Webster Street Tubes: The Posey and Webster Street tubes, also known as the Alameda Tubes, are underwater tunnels in California, United States. They are part of State Route 260 and provide a vital transportation connection between the cities of Oakland and Alameda. The immersed tube tunnels allow for efficient vehicular travel, enhancing regional accessibility and serving as essential conduits for commuters and local residents.

Ted Williams Tunnel: The Ted Williams Tunnel, located in Boston, Massachusetts, United States, is a significant transportation tunnel that forms part of the Central Artery/Tunnel Project, commonly known as the “Big Dig.” The tunnel, named after baseball player Ted Williams, is an underwater tunnel that connects the city of Boston with Logan International Airport. It incorporates immersed tube sections and plays a crucial role in improving access to the airport and reducing congestion in the urban area.

Transbay Tube: The Transbay Tube is a critical infrastructure component of the San Francisco Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART) system in California, United States. It is an immersed tube tunnel that passes beneath the San Francisco Bay, connecting the cities of San Francisco and Oakland. The Transbay Tube enables efficient and convenient transportation for thousands of commuters each day, playing a pivotal role in regional connectivity and providing a vital link in the BART network.

Sydney Harbour Tunnel: The Sydney Harbour Tunnel, situated in Sydney, Australia, is an immersed tube tunnel that passes beneath Sydney Harbour, connecting the Sydney Central Business District with the northern suburbs. The tunnel forms an integral part of the city’s road network, easing congestion on surface roads and providing a crucial transportation route for commuters traveling between the city and the northern areas of Sydney.
